title: 111_hr2526
content: The Act titled "Medical FSA Improvement Act of 2009" adds taxable distributions. The Act titled "Medical FSA Improvement Act of 2009" adds a new subsection to the Internal Revenue Code regarding amounts paid under medical flexible spending arrangements. It allows plans to distribute up to $1,500 of the employee's balance for medical care expenses without losing their flexible spending arrangement status. The Act allows plans to distribute up to $1,500 of the employee's balance for medical care expenses without losing their flexible spending arrangement status. Any distribution under this arrangement must be made by the end of the 7th month following the close of the plan year. The Act allows plans to distribute up to $1,500 of the employee's balance for medical care expenses without losing their flexible spending arrangement status. A new exception is added for certain flexible spending arrangements under section 125(d) and 409A(d)(1) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to plan years starting after December 31, 2008. Transition rules allow for new or revised elections within 90 days of the enactment of this Act for plan years before the enactment date. SEC. 3. SELF-EMPLOYED INDIVIDUALS. The amendment to section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code now includes self-employed individuals in the definition of an employee for medical flexible spending arrangements. The amount excluded under subsection (a) for a participant in a cafeteria plan who is self-employed is limited to the lesser of the employee's earned income or a specified amount. The amendment to section 125 of the Internal Revenue Code expands the definition of an employee to include self-employed individuals for medical flexible spending arrangements. The exclusion amount for self-employed participants in a cafeteria plan is limited to the lesser of earned income or a specified amount. Additionally, section 105 of the Code is amended to include self-employed individuals as employees for accident and health plans. The amendment expands the definition of an employee to include self-employed individuals for medical flexible spending arrangements. The exclusion amount for self-employed participants is limited to earned income or $5,000. The amendment expands the definition of an employee to include self-employed individuals for medical flexible spending arrangements. Any distribution to which 105(k) applies is treated as self-employment income of the employee for the taxable year. An election can be made to not apply paragraph (1) for a taxable year. Coordination with section 106(f) is also addressed. The amendments made by this section apply to plan years starting after December 31, 2008. For plan years before the enactment of this Act, a flexible spending arrangement can allow an individual to make an election within 90 days after the enactment date.
